assemblage.title: The Quadratic Formula
assemblage.p: The solutions of the equation ~~ax^2+bx+c=0,~~(a \not= 0)~~ are \blert{x=\dfrac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}}

ol.li: We have four methods for solving quadratic equations: extraction of roots, factoring, completing the square, and the quadratic formula. The first two methods are faster, but they do not work on all equations. The last two methods work on any quadratic equation.
The imaginary unit, i, is defined by i=\sqrt{-1}.
The square root of any negative number can be written as the product of a real number (the square root of its absolute value) and i.
The sum of a real number and an imaginary number is called a complex number.
The graph of the quadratic equation ~y=ax^2+bx+c may have two, one, or no x-intercepts, according to the number of distinct real-valued solutions of the equation ~ax^2+bx+c=0.

assemblage.title: The Discriminant
assemblage.p:
The discriminant of a quadratic equation is D=b^2-4ac
If D \gt 0, there are two unequal real solutions.
If D = 0, there is one solution of multiplicity two.
IfD \lt 0, there are two complex conjugate solutions.

ol.li: Every quadratic equation has two solutions, which may be the same.
Quadratic models may arise as the product of two variables.
The maximum or minimum of a quadratic equation occurs at the vertex of its graph.

assemblage.title: Vertex Form for a Quadratic Equation

ol.li: We can convert a quadratic equation to vertex form by completing the square.
We need the coordinates of three points to find the equation of a parabola.
We can use the method of elimination to find the equation of a parabola through three points.
If we know the vertex of a parabola, we need only one other point to find its equation.
We can use quadratic regression to fit a parabola to a collection of data points from a quadratic model.
We can use a graphical technique to solve quadratic inequalities.

assemblage.title: To solve a quadratic inequality algebraically

ol.li: Write the inequality in standard form: One side is zero, and the other has the form ax^2+bx+c.
Find the x-intercepts of the graph of ~y=ax^2+bx+c by setting y=0 and solving for x.
Make a rough sketch of the graph, using the sign of a to determine whether the parabola opens upward or downward.
Decide which intervals on the x-axis give the correct sign for y.
We can write the solution set to a quadratic inequality in interval notation.
The closed interval [a,b] is the set a \le x \le b.
The open interval (a,b) is the set a \lt x \lt b.
Intervals may also be half-open or half-closed.
The infinite interval [a,\infty) is the set x \ge a.
The infinite interval (\infty,a] is the set x \le a.
Determine whether the parabola opens upward (if a \gt 0) or downward (if a \lt 0).

li.p:
Locate the vertex of the parabola.
The x-coordinate of the vertex is x_v=\dfrac{-b}{2a}.
Find the y-coordinate of the vertex by substituting x_v into the equation of the parabola.

ol.li: Locate the x-intercepts (if any) by setting y=0 and solving for x.
Locate the y-intercept by evaluating y for x=0.
Locate the point symmetric to the y-intercept across the axis of symmetry.
